description: Partly onomatopoeic, and partly continuing Middle English pingen (“to push, shove, pierce, stab, prod, goad, urge, feel remorse, incite”), from Old English pyngan (“to prick”). Compare English pang.

entries.meaning: A high-pitched, short and somewhat sharp sound.
examples: My car used to make an odd ping, but after the last oil change it went away.

entries.meaning: (submarine navigation) A pulse of high-pitched or ultrasonic sound whose echoes provide information about nearby objects and vessels.
examples: The submarine sent out a ping and got an echo from a battleship.

entries.meaning: (networking) A packet which a remote host is expected to echo, thus indicating its presence.
examples: The network is overloaded from all the pings going out.

entries.meaning: (text messaging, Internet) An email or other message sent requesting acknowledgement.
examples: I sent a ping to the insurance company to see if they received our claim.
"You low ping c**t, you only win cos of your ping!"
> > And other such insights into why I was winning.

entries.meaning: (video games) A means of highlighting a feature on the game map so that allied players can see it.

verbs.description: ping (third-person singular simple present pings, present participle pinging, simple past pinged or (nonstandard) pang, past participle pinged or (nonstandard) pung)

entries.meaning: To make a high-pitched, short and somewhat sharp sound.
examples: My car was pinging until my last oil change.

entries.meaning: (submarine navigation) To emit a signal and then listen for its echo in order to detect objects.
(networking) To send a packet in order to determine whether a host is present, particularly by use of the ping utility.
(by extension) To send an email or other message to someone in hopes of eliciting a response.

examples: I pinged the crumb off the table with my finger.
The ball pinged off the wall and came hurtling back.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, sports, transitive) To cause something to bounce.

examples: Gary Ablett was pinged for holding the ball and gave away a free kick.
